author: Jasper Hamill
title: Charity hijacks Share a Coke' advertising campaign to send hard-hitting obesity message
text:
When Coke began allowing customers to choose custom messages to print on bottle labels, it sensibly banned a large number of rude words and phrases.
But it failed to remove one very powerful word which has allowed campaigners to make a vivid point about the health effects of swigging sugary drinks.
Mike Howard, CEO of the advertising company Daughters & Howard, was playing around with the 'Share a Coke' website whilst working on a campaign for the Washington-based health group Center for Science in the Public Interest.
“They have a list of words they don’t allow and some they’ll let you submit for approval or rejection,” Howard told Today.com .
The Share a Coke website allows all manner of names to be printed on bottles
“I submitted ‘obesity’ and never got an email back and then as we were working on [another] idea, we heard that ‘obesity’ was working. [The bottle] came a few days later in the mail.”
The result is a bottle of Coke with the word "obesity" emblazoned right across its front.
"Reducing soda consumption is one of our top priorities, " said Jeff Cronin, director of communications at CSPI.
This is what happens to your body after drinking Coca Cola "Coke spends billions of dollars positioning sodas as a source of happiness when it fact it causes diabetes, obesity and heart disease.
"It's more a source of sadness than happiness."
Coca Cola has now stopped people requesting the word obesity to be printed on their bottles.
However, we've found a few words which have not been banned.
